title: If the area of a circle decreases 25%, then how much decreases the circumference of this circle? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let’s define the initial area of the circle as A. Then the new circle will have an area of 0.75*A.I’ll call the inital radius of the circle r. The x in the undermentioned equation stands for the factor with which the initial radius is multiplied to get the radius of the new circle. (So r*x is the radius of the new circle.) Thus the equations we get are(1) A = π*r^2(2) 0.75*A = π * (r*x)^2 = π * r^2 * x^2Rewriting (1) and (2) givesr^2 = A/πr^2 = 0.75*A/(π*x^2)(For the sake of clarity, “r” represents the radius of the initial circle and not the one of the new; see my definitions at the beginning.) And we know that r^2 = r^2, so apparently A/π = 0.75*A/(π*x^2)I want to find the value of x. Multiplying both sides by π and dividing both sides by A gives1 = 0.75/x^2So x^2 = 0.75x = sqrt(0.75) The circumference of the initial circle was 2*π*r. The circumference of the new circle is 2*π*r*x = 2*π*r*sqrt(0.75) Hence the decrease in circumference is2*π*r - 2*π*r*sqrt(0.75) = 2*π*r*(1-sqrt(0.75)) As a percentage of the initial circumference, this is equal to2*π*r*(1-sqrt(0.75)) / (2*π*r) * 100% = (1-sqrt(0.75)) * 100% ≈ 13.4% Hope this helped :)

[math]\mathcal{A} = \pi r^2[/math] [math]\mathcal{C} = 2\pi r[/math] [math]\mathcal{A} = \frac1{4\pi}\mathcal{C}^2[/math] [math]\frac{\mathcal{A}'}{\mathcal{A}} = \frac{\mathcal{C}'^2}{\mathcal{C}^2}[/math] [math]\frac{\mathcal{C}'}{\mathcal{C}} = \sqrt{\frac{\mathcal{A}'}{\mathcal{A}}}[/math] All that to say, the ratio of the circumferences evolves as the square root of the ratio of the areas. If the area decreases by [math]25\%[/math], then the ratio is [math]0.75[/math], which means the ratio of the circumferences is about [math]0.866[/math], which finally means the circumference decreases by about [math]13.4\%[/math].
